title: Cheaper gas caps consumer inflation in August, CPI shows, but price pressures appear to be rising
text:
Bloomberg News/Landov Coins inflation prices.

The numbers: Falling oil prices kept consumer inflation in check in August, but higher prices for staples such as health care, rent and airfares put more stress on the finances of U.S. households.

The consumer price index rose 0.1% last month, the government said Thursday, matching the MarketWatch forecast.

The increase in the cost of living has risen just 1.7% over the past 12 months, government figures show, largely because of a sharp drop in the cost of oil.

Yet if gas prices are set aside, inflation appears to have accelerated since the beginning of summer. Another closely watched measure of inflation that strips out food and energy rose 0.3% for the third month in a row.

The yearly increase in the so-called core rate advanced to 2.4%, matching a 13-month high. The last time the core rate of inflation was higher was in 2008.

The latest stirring of inflation is unlikely to deter the Federal Reserve from cutting interest rates next week, but the central bank is watching closely.

Read: Weak unions, globalization not to blame for shrinking slice of income pie for workers

What happened: Gas prices fell in August more than they usually do as the summer driving season tapered off. The cost of food was also flat.

Prices rose for medical care, including prescription drugs. The cost of medical care has risen in the past 12 months at the fastest pace in two and a half years.

The cost of rent, used vehicles, airfares and recreational goods also rose.

After adjusting for inflation, hourly wages jumped 0.4%. They have risen a solid 1.5% in the past year.

Read: U.S. consumers are far from spent and that’s a lifesaver for a wobbly economy

Big picture: Inflation appears to be climbing back toward 2% or even higher after a big drop early in the year, but the Federal Reserve is still on track to cut interest rates next week.

Most Fed officials simply aren’t bothered about inflation right now after years of weak readings. They are more worried about the damage the U.S. trade war with China could cause to the economy. So far tariffs have had little effect on inflation, but the spat has harmed exports and business investment.

If prices keep rising and the economy continues to slow, however, the Fed could face a quandary later in the year or early in 2020. For now the risks seem low.
